message.content:
<<<api>>>: InputStream.read
<<<code>>>: try {
    byte[] readBuffer = new byte[20];
    while (inStream.available() > 0) {
        int numBytes = inStream.read(readBuffer);
    }
    String result = new String(readBuffer);
    System.out.println("Read: " + result);
} catch (IOException e) {
    System.out.println(e);
}
<<<explanation>>>: The InputStream.read() method is used to read from the input stream. In this case, we are reading from the input stream of the serial port. We first create a byte array buffer to store the data read from the input stream. Then, we use a while loop to keep reading from the input stream as long as there are available bytes. The read() method returns the number of bytes actually read. Finally, we convert the byte array to a string and print it out. If there is an IOException, we print the exception.
